key_title: Key to the species of Wahlenbergia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Campanulaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Wahlenbergia
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1999). Wahlenbergia. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Rhizomatous perennials; aerial stems simple or sparingly branched, 1 (2–3)- flowered; often alpine or subalpine
Tufted perennials or annuals; aerial stems of perennials usually branched and several-flowered (but annuals often unbranched and 1-flowered); mostly lowlands (but occasionally subalpine)
Leaves more than 2 mm wide (basal leaves usually 5 mm wide or more); alps and subalps only
Leaves linear, narrowly elliptic or narrowly obovate, to 2 mm wide (or basal leaves sometimes slightly wider); alps and lowlands
Flowers pale blue to pale violet; stems erect; leaves alternate, margins flat and entire; virtually glabrous plants of damp to wet treeless sites
Flowers rich purple; stems spreading to ascending; some or most leaves opposite, margins undulate and often crenate or toothed; basally hirsute plants, usually in wooded areas
Leaves under 15 mm long; style usually 2-fid; plants to c. 20 cm high; rare, in eastern alps
Leaves mostly longer than 15 mm; style usually 3-fid; plants more than 20 cm (to 60 cm) high; lowland (often near-coastal) to foothills

Stigma capitate, with 3 ovate lobes as long as they are wide; style constricted just below stigma-lobes (i.e. in upper third); corolla rotate, lobes widely spreading, usually more than 4 times as long as tube; calyx-lobes equal to or longer than corolla-tube

Stigma with 2 or 3 oblong to linear lobes longer than they are wide; style unconstricted or constricted about midway (distinctly below the stigma-lobes); corolla campanulate, lobes less than 4 times as long as tube; calyx-lobes often shorter than corolla-tube
Capsule narrowly obconical, more than twice as long as wide; corolla-lobes (2–) 4–9 mm long, less than twice the length of the hypanthium; widespread
Capsule hemispherical to obconical or obovoid, less than twice as long as wide; corolla-lobes more than twice as long as hypanthium; on or north of the Dividing Range
Corolla-lobes 3–9 mm long; lower leaves oblanceolate to linear, to 5 mm wide; plants usually many-stemmed; northern and western Victoria
Corolla-lobes 6–13 mm long; lower leaves obovate to oblanceolate, to 10 mm wide; plants usually few-stemmed; north-eastern to eastern Victoria
At least the lower leaves opposite, linear; capsules narrow-obconical, at least 3 times longer than wide; flowers often yellowish outside
Leaves all alternate, or if opposite, then broader than linear and capsules less than 3 times longer than wide; flowers blue or whitish outside (rarely yellowish)
Perennials developing thickened woody taproots (remaining when stems pulled up), few-many-stemmed
Annuals with slender taproots (usually pulling up with the plant), often single- stemmed
Leaves all opposite, or the uppermost alternate
Leaves all alternate, or opposite at base only
Corolla-lobes (5–) 6–20 mm long
Corolla-lobes 0.5–6 mm long
Corolla-lobes 1–2 times as long as the tube; hypanthium and capsule elongate, usually at least 3 times as long as wide
Corolla-lobes 2–4 times as long as the tube; hypanthium and capsule usually less than 3 times longer than wide
Capsules obconical to obovoid; stems often many-branched; widespread, but apparently not in far north-west
Capsules globose to barrel-shaped; stems few-branched; north and north-west only
Corolla-lobes (6–) 8–12 mm long
Corolla-lobes 0.5–5 (–6.5) mm long
Leaves opposite for at least 2 nodes; usually distinctly hirsute to upper leaves; capsules often hirsute; widespread
Leaves alternate above first or second node; glabrous or sparsely hirsute near base only; capsules glabrous; north and north-west only
